Definition: In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events will be short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people will have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX will always be the subject of the event. You will need to determine whether the Head includes an event or an action in the Tail or not. This happens when the Tail denotes a step within the larger head event. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Physical Commonsense
Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.input: Head: have conversation<sep>Tail: choose subject to discuss
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. The Head includes the event of choosing a subject the Tail.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX allergic to bees<sep>Tail: none
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, there isn't any action or event in the Tail. So the output should be"No".
In this example, designing software includes checking the design. Thus, this example should be classified as "Yes".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX asks to go home<sep>Tail: to go rest
Negative Examples.explanation: Asking to go home doesn't include going rest. So the output should be "No".
The communicate includes gathering the thoughts, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: go to performance<sep>Tail: applaud when show over
Head: PersonX always watch ___<sep>Tail: PersonX can't help but watch
Head: PersonX babysits PersonX's nephew<sep>Tail: plays
Head: PersonX becomes PersonY's wife<sep>Tail: complete, happy
Head: PersonX amends PersonY act<sep>Tail: none
Head: PersonX asks PersonY's grandma<sep>Tail: thinks about answer
Head: take phone call<sep>Tail: answer phone
